question.title: how should I access things of other directory in the same path in java
question.body:
I have the following file directories:

project/
│
├── A/
│   └── Fuel.java
│
└── B/
    └── Car.java

package A;

public class Fuel{
    public static fuelLevel(){
        ...
    }
}

package B;
import A.*;

public class Car{
    Fuel.fuelLevel();
}

If I do the above thing to access a method fuelLevel() from class Fuel.java, I am getting an error that the package cannot be resolved. Please tell me how I can access the method fuelLevel() from the class Car.

Error Message: The import A cannot be resolved, Java(268435846)

answers.body:
This is why we have build systems.

Without these, a few simple rules to work with java files with just the command line tools:

  1. Projects have a root directory.
  2. You must always be in this root directory when doing anything.
  3. package + type name must match a relative path that gets you from the root to that file's content.
  4. Type names are their package name plus a dot plus their type name.

To illustrate point 3: You have on your drive:

  • /home/projects/mycoolproj/A/Fuel.java
  • /home/projects/mycoolproj/B/Car.java

That 'works', if we treat /home/projects/mycoolproj as your project root. You can then run:

cd /home/projects/mycoolproj
javac -classpath . A/Fuel.java B/Car.java
java -classpath . A.Fuel # Assuming Fuel.java has a `main` method.

and it'll all work without error or warning. And usually you don't need the -classpath . option, but it depends on your environment, so for an SO answer that should be widely applicable, best to include it; it won't hurt.

The arguments to javac are file paths. The argument to java is a fully qualified type name. hence A/Fuel.java (with a slash) when invoking javac and A.Fuel (a dot instead of a slash, and no .java) when invoking java.

If you delve even a tiny little bit deeper into this, such as:

  • I want to compile parts of the project separate from other parts
  • I have non-java resources
  • I want to script the downloading and inclusion on the classpath of my dependencies
  • I have many packages and listing out all the source files to javac is becoming onerous

You should use a build system; quite a few exist; maven and gradle are the most popular by quite a margin as of time of writing.

NB: There's a "hack" Where you compile only your Main java file (the one with your main method) and use -sourcepath so the compiler treeshakes its way into a full build. This is a bad idea for a number of reasons. Just.. use a build system. I write it here only so that you recognize when you read this advice, that it isn't a panacea and probably not something you should be investing much time in.

Issues in your code

1.In Fuel.java file return type is missing

2.If it is void type then you have to call inside the method of Car class

while you running the code..

1. Make sure you are in root folder of those package then compile both packages and run the java file which contains main method in it

question_comments.body: Which IDE are you using? What is the source path configuration?
Did you make sure that you compiled your code from the root directory ?
Please edit your question to include a detailed description how you try to compile your source code.
@Progman I have added the full error message
